ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned much about black art history and its implication on black culture as much as it can be thought of as a singular unit.
Black cultural theory from the US, England, Cuba. A really good blend of history, art, and theory.
I learned about a plethora of Black artists and cultural workers/theorists. The class gave me the vocabulary/tools to think further about and through Black diasporic cultural production.
Knowledge of several topics related to Black art, music, dance, and theories of culture.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course couldve been better with a bit more historical context around artworks we analysed. However this is a small gripe. The assignments really helped me understand the material, and professors insights were always germane.

This course was all strengths! It was amazing to read and discuss important theorists like WEB Du Bois, Sylvia Wynter, and Paul Gilroy, combined with looking at art from different time periods. I hope Black Cultural Theory continues to be offered as a course as Yale!
Professor Mercer is an absolute gem! He teaches with such a deep level of care and attention! The readings were consistently incredible and the course's flexibility was so appreciated.
Excellently taught, I can't think of any weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the discussion posts. It would have been nice to have to respond to our classmate's posts to add even more interaction.
General understanding for difficulties faced by students.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes if you want to learn more about how to analyse art forms, and black cultural history

Yes, definitely! It was a wonderful course for anyone interested in the subject. I would highly recommend to both students who have a background in art history/AFAM but also any interested student because of the important and engaging subject matter.
Absolutely!! This course is so essential!!
Absolutely, take a class with Prof. Mercer during your time here - you won't regret it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
